div.head: A Di≈øcour≈øe concerning PRAYER Ex tempore, &c.
div.p: I Have read over this Book which the A≈ø≈øembly of Divines is plea≈øed to call The Directory for Prayer; I confe≈ø≈øe I came to it with much expectation, and was in ≈øome mea≈øure confident I ≈øhould have found it an exact and unblameable modell of Devotion, free from all tho≈øe objections which men of their own per≈øwa≈øion had obtruded again≈øt the publike Liturgy of the Church of England; or at lea≈øt, it ≈øhould have been compo≈øed with ≈øo much artifice and finene≈ø≈øe, that it might have been to all the world an Argument of their learning and excellency of ≈øpirit, if not of the goodne≈ø≈øe and integrity of their Religion and purpo≈øes. I ≈øhall give no other character of the whole, but that the publike di≈øreli≈øh which I finde among≈øt per≈øons of great piety, of all qualities, not only of great, but even of ordinary under≈øtandings, is to, me ≈øome argument that it lies ≈øo open to the objections even of common ≈øpirits, that the Compilers of it did intend more to prevaile by the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of their Armies, then the ≈øtrength of rea≈øon, and the proper grounds of per≈øwa≈øion, which yet mo≈øt wi≈øe and good men believe to be the more Chri≈øtian way of the two. But Sir, you have engaged me to ≈øay ≈øomething in particular to ≈øatisfie your con≈øcience. In which al≈øo I de≈øire I may re≈øerve a leave to my ≈øelf to conceal much, if I may in little doe you ≈øatisfaction.

Numb. 2 I ≈øhall therefore decline to ≈øpeak of the Efficient can≈øe of this Directory, and not quarrell at it that is was compo≈øed, again≈øt the Lawes both of England and all Chri≈øtendome. If the thing were good and pious, I ≈øhould learn to ≈øubmit to the impo≈øition, and never quarrell at the incompetency of his authority that engaged me to doe pious and holy things. And it may be when I am a little more u≈øed to it, I ≈øhall not wonder at a Synod, in which not one Bi≈øhop ≈øits (in the capacity of a Bi≈øhop) though I am mo≈øt certain this is the fir≈øt example in England, ≈øince it was fir≈øt Chri≈øtned. But for pre≈øent it ≈øeemes ≈øomething hard to dige≈øt it, becau≈øe I know ≈øo well that all A≈ø≈øemblies of the Church have admitted Prie≈øts to con≈øultation and di≈øpute, but never to authority and deci≈øion, till the Pope enlarging the phylacteries of the Archimandrites and Abbots, did ≈øometimes by way of priviledge and di≈øpen≈øation give to ≈øome of them deci≈øive voyces in publike Councels. But this was one of the things in which he did innovate and invade again≈øt the publike re≈øolutions of Chri≈øtendome, though he dur≈øt not doe it often, and when he did it, it was in very ≈ømall and incon≈øiderate numbers.

Numb. 3 I ≈øaid I would not meddle with the Efficient, and I cannot meddle with the Finall cau≈øe, nor gue≈ø≈øe at any other ends and purpo≈øes of theirs then at what they publiquely profe≈ø≈øe, which is the abolition and de≈øtruction of the Book of Common-Prayer; which great change, becau≈øe they are plea≈øed to call Reformation, I am content in charity to believe they think it ≈øo, and that they have Zelum Dei, but whether ≈øecundum ≈øcientiam, according to knowledge or no, mu≈øt be judged by them who con≈øider the matter and the forme.

Numb. 4 But becau≈øe the matter is of ≈øo great variety and minute con≈øideration, every part whereof would require as much ≈øcrutiny as I purpo≈øe to be≈øtow upon the whole, I have for the pre≈øent cho≈øen to con≈øider only the form of it; and becau≈øe it pretends again≈øt the form of ≈øet Lyturgy and that ex tempore forms doe ≈øucceed in room of the e≈øtabli≈øhed and determined ≈øervices, I ≈øhall give you my judgement of it, without any ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe or bitterne≈ø≈øe of ≈øpirit, for I am re≈øolved not
to be angry with any man of another per≈øwa≈øion, as knowing that I differ ju≈øt as much from them as they doe from me.

Numb. 5 And fir≈øt, I con≈øider that the true ≈øtate of the Que≈øtion is only this, Whether it is better to pray to God with con≈øideration or without? whether is the wi≈øer man of the two, hee who thinks, and deliberates what to ≈øay, or he that utters his mind as fa≈øt as it comes? Whether is the better man, he who out of reverence to God is mo≈øt carefull and curious that he offend not in his tongue, and therefore he him≈øelfe deliberates and takes the be≈øt guides he can, or he who out of the con≈øiderce of his own abilities or other exteriour a≈ø≈øi≈øtances, ≈øpeaks what ever comes uppermo≈øt?

Numb. 6 And here I have the advice and councell of a very wi≈øe man, no le≈ø≈øe than Solomon, Eccle≈ø. 5.2. Be not ra≈øh with thy mouth, and let not thy heart be ha≈øty to utter any thing before God, for God is in heaven and thou upon earth, therefore, let thy words be few. The con≈øideration of the va≈øt di≈øtance between God and us, Heaven and Earth, ≈øhould create ≈øuch apprehen≈øions in us, that the very be≈øt and choyce≈øt of our offertoryes are not acceptable but by Gods gracious vouch≈øafeing and conde≈øcen≈øion: and therefore ≈øince we are ≈øo much indebted to God for accepting our be≈øt, it is not ≈øafe ventured to pre≈øent him with a dowbaked ≈øacrifice, and put him off with that which in nature and humane con≈øideration is ab≈øolutely the wor≈øt; for ≈øuch is all the crude and imperfect utterance of our more imperfect conceptions. But let Solomons rea≈øon be what it will, good we are ≈øure it is. Let us con≈øider who keeps the precept be≈øt; He that deliberates, or he that con≈øiders not but when he ≈øpeakes: What man in the world is ha≈øty to offer any thing before God, if he bee not who prayes ex tempore? And then adde to it but the weight of Solomons rea≈øon, and let any man an≈øwer me if he thinks it can well ≈øtand with that reverence we owe to the Immen≈øe, the infinite, and to the eternall God, the God of wi≈ødome, to offer him a ≈øacrifice which we dur≈øt not pre≈øent to a Prince, or a prudent Governour in re ≈øeri√¢, ≈øuch as our prayers ought to be.

Numb. 7 And that this may not be da≈øhed with a pretence it is carnall
rea≈øoning I de≈øire it may be remembred, that it is the argument God him≈øelfe u≈øes again≈øt lame, maimed, and imperfect ≈øacrifices, Goe and offer this to thy Prince, ≈øee if he will accept it: Implying, that the be≈øt per≈øon is to have the be≈øt pre≈øent; and what the Prince will ≈ølight as truly unworthy of him, much more is it unfit for God. For God accepts not of any thing we give or doe, as if he were bettred by it: for therefore its e≈øtimate is not taken by its relation or naturall complacency to him, it is all alike to him, for in it ≈øelfe it is to him as nothing. But God accepts it by its proportion, and commen≈øuration to us. That which we call our be≈øt, and is truly ≈øo in humane e≈øtimate, that plea≈øes God, for it declares that if we had better, we would give it him. But to re≈øerve the be≈øt, ≈øayes too plainly, that we think any thing is good enough for him. As therefore God in the Law would not be ≈øerved by that which was imperfect in genere naturae: ≈øo neither now nor ever will that plea≈øe him which is imperfect in geuere morum, or materi√¢ intellectuali, when we can give a better.

Numb. 8 Well then, in the nature of the thing, ex tempore forms have much the wor≈øe of it. But it is pretended that there is ≈øuch a thing as the gift of Prayer, a praying with the Spirit, Et ne≈øcit tarda molimina ≈øpiritus ≈øancti gratia. Gods Spirit (if he plea≈øes) can doe his work as well in an in≈øtant, as in long premeditation. And to this purpo≈øe are pretended tho≈øe places of Scripture which ≈øpeak of the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Gods Spirit in our prayers, Zech. 12.10. And I will poure upon the hou≈øe of David, and the inhabitants of Jeru≈øalem, the ≈øpirit of grace and ≈øupplication. But e≈øpecially Rom. 8.26. Likewi≈øe the Spirit al≈øo helpeth our infirmities; for we know not what we ≈øhould pray for as we ought, but the Spirit it ≈øelfe maketh interce≈ø≈øion for us with groanings that cannot be uttered, &c. From whence the Conclu≈øion that is inferred is in the words of Saint Paul, That we mu≈øt pray with the ≈øpirit, therefore not with ≈øet forms, therefore ex tempore.

Numb. 9 The Collection is ≈øomewhat wild; for there is great independence in the ≈øeverall parts, and much more is in the Conclu≈øion, then was virtually in the premi≈øes. But ≈øuch as it is, the
Authors of it I ≈øuppo≈øe will own it. And therefore we will examine the maine de≈øign of it, and then con≈øider the particular meanes of its per≈øwa≈øion, quoted in the objection.

Numb. 10 It is one of the priviledges of the Go≈øpel, and the benefit of Chri≈øts a≈øcen≈øion, that the holy Gho≈øt is given unto the Church, and is become to us the fountaine of gifts and graces. But the≈øe gifts and graces are improvements and helps of our naturall faculties, of our art and indu≈øtry, not extraordinary, miraculous, and immediate infu≈øions of habits and gifts. That without Gods Spirit we cannot pray aright; that our infirmities need his help; that we know not what to ask of our ≈øelves, is mo≈øt true: and if ever any Heretique was more confident of his own naturals, or did ever more undervalue Gods grace then ever the Pelagians did, yet he denyes not this. But what then? Therefore without ≈øtudy, without art, without premeditation, without learning, the ≈øpirit gives the gift of prayer, and it is his grace, that without any naturall or artificiall help makes us pray ex tempore? No ≈øuch thing: The Objection proves nothing of this.

Numb. 11 Here therefore we will joyn i≈ø≈øue, whether the gifts and helps of the Spirit be immediate infu≈øions of the Faculties, and powers, and perfect abilities? Or that he doth a≈ø≈øi≈øt us only by his aydes externall and internall, in the u≈øe of ≈øuch means which God and nature hath given to man, to ennoble his ≈øoul, better his Faculties, and to improve his under≈øtanding? That the aydes of the holy Gho≈øt are only a≈ø≈øi≈øtances to us in the u≈øe of naturall and artificiall means, I will undertake to prove, and from thence it will evidently follow, that labour, and hard ≈øtudy, and premeditation will ≈øoone≈øt purcha≈øe the gift of prayer, and a≈øcertain us of the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the ≈øpirit; and therefore ≈øet forms of prayer, ≈øtudyed and con≈øidered of are in a true and proper ≈øen≈øe, and without enthu≈øia≈øm, the fruits of the ≈øpirit.

Numb. 12 1. Gods Spirit did a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Apo≈øtles by wayes extraordinary, and fit for the fir≈øt in≈øtitution of Chri≈øtianity: but doth a≈ø≈øi≈øt us row by the expre≈ø≈øes of tho≈øe fir≈øt a≈ø≈øi≈øtances which he gave to them immediately. So that the holy Gho≈øt is the author of cur ≈øaith, and we believe with the ≈øpirit (it is Saint Pauls expre≈ø≈øion)
and yet our beliefe comes by hearing and reading the holy Scriptures and their interpretations. Now reconcile the≈øe two together, Faith comes by hearing, and yet is the gift of the Spirit, and it ≈øayes, that the gifts of the Spirit are not exta≈øies, and immediate infu≈øions of habits, but helps from God to enable us upon the u≈øe of the meanes of his own appointment to believe, to ≈øpeak, to under≈øtand, to prophecy, and to pray.

Numb. 13 2. And that the≈øe are for this rea≈øon called gifts, and graces, and i≈ø≈øues of the Spirit, is ≈øo evident and notorious, that the ≈øpeaking of an ordinary revealed truth, is called in Scripture a ≈øpeaking by the Spirit,
Vid. Act. 19.21. Act. 16.7, 8, 9, 10. 1 Cor. 12.8. No man can ≈øay that Je≈øut is the Lord, but by the holy Gho≈øt. For if the holy Gho≈øt ≈øupplyes us with materials, and fundamentals for our building, it is then enough to denominate the whole edifice to be of him, although the labour and the workman≈øhip be ours, upon anothers ≈øtock. Which things al≈øo we ≈øpeak, not in the words which mans wi≈ødome teacheth, but which the holy Gho≈øt teacheth, comparing ≈øpirituall things with ≈øpirituall. The holy Gho≈øt teaches, yet it is upon our co-operation, our ≈øtudy and endeavour, while we compare ≈øpirituall things with ≈øpirituall; the holy Gho≈øt is ≈øaid to teach us, becau≈øe the≈øe ≈øpirituals were of his ≈øugge≈øtion and revelation.

Numb. 14 3. For it is a rule of the Schools, and there is much rea≈øon in it. Habitus infu≈øi infunduntur per modum acqui≈øitorum, what≈øoever is infu≈øed into us, is in the ≈øame manner infu≈øed as other things are acquired, that is, ≈øtep by ≈øtep, by humane meanes and co-operation, and grace does not give us new faculties, and create another nature, but meliorates and improves our own. And what S. Paul ≈øaid in the Re≈øurrection, is al≈øo true in this Que≈øtion, That is not fir≈øt which is ≈øpirituall, but that which is naturall, and then that which is ≈øpirituall. The graces and gifts of the Spirit are po≈øtnate, and are additions to art and nature. God directs our councels, opens our under≈øtandings, regulates our will, orders our affections, ≈øupplies us with Objects, and Arguments, and opportunities, and revelations in ≈øcriptis, and then mo≈øt when we mo≈øt imploy our own endeavours,
God loving to ble≈ø≈øe all the meanes, and in≈øtruments of his ≈øervice, whether they be naturall or acqui≈øite.

Numb. 15 But who≈øoever ≈øhall look for any other gifts of the ≈øpirit be≈øides the parts of nature helped by indu≈øtry and Gods ble≈ø≈øing upon it, and the revelations or the ≈øuppplyes of matter in holy Scripture, will be very farre to ≈øeek, having neither rea≈øon, promi≈øe, nor experience of his ≈øide. Paul calls it, 2 Cor. 4.13) acquired by humane meanes u≈øing divine aids? that is, by our endeavours in hearing, reading, Catechizing, de≈øires to obey, and all this ble≈ø≈øed and promoted by God, this produces faith. Numb. 16 4. And the parallel of this Argument I the rather urge, becau≈øe I find praying in the holy Gho≈øt joyned with graces, which are as much Gods gifts and productions of the ≈øpirit as any thing in the world, and yet which the Apo≈øtle pre≈ø≈øes upon us as duties and things put into our power, and to be improved by our indu≈øtry, and tho≈øe are faith (in which I before in≈øtanced) and charity, Epi≈øt. Jud. ver. 20. But ye (beloved) building up your ≈øelves on your most holy Faith, praying in the holy Gho≈øt, keep your ≈øelves in the love of God. Holy prayers, ≈øpirituall ≈øongs, ≈øo the Apo≈øtle calls one part of prayer, viz. Euchari≈øticall or thank≈øgiving, that is, prayers or ≈øongs which are ≈øpirituall in materi√¢.
